Barchielli | title = Measurement theory and stochastic differential equations in quantum mechanics | journal = Phys. Rev. A | volume = 34 | issue = 3 | pages = 1642–1649 | year = 1986 | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevA.34.1642 | url = http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevA.34.1642 | bibcode = 1986PhRvA..34.1642B }}</ref> [[Carlton M. Caves|Caves]];<ref name="Caves1986">{{cite journal | author = Carlton M. Caves | title = Quantum mechanics of measurements distributed in time. A path-integral formulation | journal = Phys. Rev. D | volume = 33 | issue = 6 | pages = 1643–1665 | year = 1986 | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevD.33.1643 | url = http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevD.33.1643 | bibcode = 1986PhRvD..33.1643C }}</ref><ref name="Caves1987">{{cite journal | author = Carlton M. Caves | title = Quantum mechanics of measurements distributed in time. II. Connections among formulations | journal = Phys. Rev. D | volume = 35 | issue = 6 | pages = 1815–1830 | year = 1987 | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevD.35.1815 | url = http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevD.35.1815 | bibcode = 1987PhRvD..35.1815C }}</ref> Caves and [[Gerard J. Milburn|Milburn]].<ref name="CavesMilburn1987">{{cite journal | author1 = Carlton M. Caves | author2 = G. J. Milburn, | title = Quantum-mechanical model for continuous position measurements | journal = Phys. Rev. A | volume = 36 | issue = 12 | pages = 5543–5555 | year = 1987 | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevA.36.5543 | url = http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevA.36.5543 |bibcode = 1987PhRvA..36.5543C }}</ref> Later on [[Howard Carmichael]] <ref name="Carmichael">{{cite book |title= An open systems approach to quantum optics, Lecture Notes in Physics|last= Carmichael|first= Howard |year= 1993|publisher= [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]]|location= ;}}</ref> and [[Howard M. Wiseman]]<ref>[http://library.uq.edu.au/search~S7?/awiseman%2C+h/awiseman+h/1%2C9%2C24%2CB/frameset&FF=awiseman+howard+mark&1%2C1%2C Wiseman's thesis]</ref> also made important contributions to the field.
It should be noted that the notion of a weak measurement is often misattributed to [[Yakir Aharonov|Aharonov]], [[David Albert|Albert]] and [[Lev Vaidman|Vaidman]].<ref name="Aharonov1988"/> In their article they consider an example of a weak measurement (and perhaps coin the phrase "weak measurement") and use it to motivate their definition of a [[weak value]], which they defined there for the first time.
== Mathematics==
There is no universally accepted definition of a weak measurement. One approach is to declare a weak measurement to be a generalized measurement where some or all of the [[Kraus operators]] are close to the identity.<ref name="OreshkovBrun2005" /> The approach taken below is to interact two systems weakly and then measure one of them.<ref name="Wiseman and Milburn"/> After detailing this approach we will illustrate it with examples.
===Weak interaction and ancilla coupled measurement===
Consider a system that starts in the [[quantum state]] <math>|\psi\rangle</math> and an ancilla that starts in the state <math>|\phi\rangle</math>, the combined initial state is <math>|\Psi\rangle = |\psi\rangle \otimes |\phi\rangle</math>. These two systems interact via the [[Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics)|Hamiltonian]] <math>H = A \otimes B</math>, which generates the time evolutions <math>U(t) = \exp[-ixtH] </math> (in units where <math>\hbar = 1</math>), where <math>x</math> is the "interaction strength", which has units of inverse time. Assume a fixed interaction time <math>t = \Delta t</math> and that <math>\lambda = x \Delta t</math> is small, such that <math>\lambda^3 \approx 0</math>. A series expansion of <math>U</math> in <math>\lambda</math> gives
:<math> \begin{align} U &= I \otimes I - i\lambda H - \frac 1 2 \lambda^2 H^2 + O(\lambda^3) \\ &\approx I \otimes I - i\lambda A \otimes B - \frac 1 2 \lambda^2 A^2 \otimes B^2. \end{align} </math>
Because it was only necessary to expand the unitary to a low order in perturbation theory, we call this is a weak interaction. Further, the fact that the unitary is predominately the identity operator, as <math>\lambda</math> and <math>\lambda^2</math> are small, implies that the state after the interaction is not radically different from the initial state. The combined state of the system after interaction is
:<math> |\Psi'\rangle = \left(I \otimes I - i\lambda A \otimes B - \frac 1 2 \lambda^2 A^2 \otimes B^2\right) |\Psi\rangle. </math>
Now we perform a measurement on the ancilla to find out about the system, this is known as an ancilla-coupled measurement. We will consider measurements in a basis <math>|q\rangle</math> (on the ancilla system) such that <math>\sum_q |q\rangle \langle q| = I</math>. The measurements action on both systems is described by the action of the projectors <math>\Pi_q = I \otimes |q\rangle \langle q|</math> on the joint state <math>|\Psi'\rangle</math>. From [[Measurement in quantum mechanics|quantum measurement theory]] we know the conditional state after the measurement is
:<math> \begin{align} |\Psi_q\rangle &= \frac{\Pi_q |\Psi'\rangle}{\sqrt{\langle\Psi'| \Pi_q |\Psi'\rangle}} \\ &= \frac{I \langle q|\phi\rangle - i\lambda A \langle q| B |\phi\rangle - \frac 1 2 \lambda^2 A^2 \langle q| B^2 |\phi\rangle}{\mathcal N} |\psi\rangle \otimes |q\rangle, \end{align} </math>
where <math>\mathcal N = \sqrt{\langle\Psi'| \Pi_q |\Psi'\rangle}</math> is a normalization factor for the wavefunction. Notice the ancilla system state records the outcome of the measurement. The object <math>M_q := I \langle q|\phi\rangle - i\lambda A \langle q| B |\phi\rangle - \frac 1 2 \lambda^2 A^2 \langle q| B^2 |\phi\rangle</math> is an operator on the system Hilbert space and is called a [[Kraus operators|Kraus operator]].
With respect to the Kraus operators the post-measurement state of the combined system is
:<math> |\Psi_q\rangle = \frac{M_q |\psi\rangle}{\sqrt{\langle \psi|M_q^\dagger M_q|\psi\rangle}} \otimes |q\rangle. </math>
The objects <math>E_q = M_q^\dagger M_q </math> are elements of what is called a [[POVM]] and must obey <math>\sum_q E_q = I</math> so that the corresponding probabilities sum to unity: <math>\sum_q \Pr(q|\psi) = \sum_q \langle\psi| E_q |\psi\rangle = 1</math>. As the ancilla system is no longer correlated with the primary system, it is simply recording the outcome of the measurement, we can [[Partial trace|trace]] over it. Doing so gives the conditional state of the primary system alone:
:<math> |\psi_q\rangle = \frac{M_q |\psi\rangle}{\sqrt{\langle \psi|M_q^\dagger M_q|\psi\rangle}}, </math>
which we still label by the outcome of the measurement <math>q</math>. Indeed, these considerations allow one to derive a [[Quantum stochastic calculus#Quantum trajectories|quantum trajectory]].
===Example Kraus operators=== We will use the canonical example of Gaussian Kraus operators given by Barchielli, Lanz, Prosperi;<ref name="Barchiellietal1982"/> and Caves and Milburn.<ref name="CavesMilburn1987" /> Take <math>H = x \otimes p</math>, where the position and momentum on both systems have the usual [[Canonical commutation relation]] <math>[x, p] = i</math>. Take the initial wavefunction of the ancilla to have a Gaussian distribution
:<math> |\Phi\rangle = \frac{1}{(2\pi\sigma^2)^{1/4}} \int dq' \exp[-q'^2/(4\sigma^2)] |q'\rangle. </math>
The position wavefunction of the ancilla is
:<math> \Phi(q) = \langle q|\Phi\rangle = \frac{1}{(2\pi\sigma^2)^{1/4}} \exp[-q^2/(4\sigma^2)]. </math>
The Kraus operators are (compared to the discussion above, we set <math>\lambda = 1</math>)
:<math> \begin{align} M(q) &= \langle q| \exp[-ix \otimes p] |\Phi\rangle \\ &= \frac{1}{(2\pi\sigma^2)^{1/4}} \exp[-(q - x)^2/(4\sigma^2)], \end{align} </math>
while the corresponding POVM elements are
:<math> \begin{align} E(q) &= M_q^\dagger M_q \\ &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}} \exp[-(q - x)^2/(2\sigma^2)], \end{align} </math>
which obey <math>\int dq\, E(q) = I</math>. An alternative representation is often seen in the literature. Using the spectral representation of the position operator <math>x = \int dx' |x'\rangle \langle x'|</math>, we can write
:<math> \begin{align} M(q) &= \frac{1}{(2\pi\sigma^2)^{1/4}} \int dx' \exp[-(q - x')^2/(4\sigma^2)] |x'\rangle \langle x'|, \\ E(q) &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}} \int dx' \exp[-(q - x')^2/(2\sigma^2)] |x'\rangle \langle x'|. \end{align} </math>
Notice that <math>\lim_{\sigma \to 0} E(q) = |x = q\rangle \langle x = q| </math>.<ref name="CavesMilburn1987" /> That is, in a particular limit these operators limit to a strong measurement of position; for other values of <math>\sigma</math> we refer to the measurement as finite-strength; and as <math>\sigma \to \infty</math>, we say the measurement is weak.
==Information-gain–disturbance tradeoff== As stated above, Busch's theorem prevents a free lunch: there can be no information gain without disturbance. However, the tradeoff between information gain and disturbance has been characterized by many authors, including Fuchs and [[Asher Peres|Peres]];<ref name="FuchsPeres1996">{{cite journal | author1 = C. ==Applications==
Since the early days it has been clear that the primary use of weak measurement would be for feedback control or adaptive measurements of quantum systems. Indeed, this motivated much of Belavkin's work, and an explicit example was given by Caves and Milburn. An early application of an adaptive weak measurements was that of [http://coding.jpl.nasa.gov/sdolinar Dolinar]'s receiver,<ref name="Dolinar1973">{{cite journal | author = S. J. Dolinar | title = An optimum receiver for the binary coherent state quantum channel | journal = MIT Res. Lab. Electron. Quart. Progr. Rep. | volume = 111 | pages = 115–120 | year = 1973 }}</ref> which has been realized experimentally<ref name="Cook">{{cite journal | author1 = R. L. Cook | author2 = P. J. Martin | author3 =J. M. Geremia | title = Optical coherent state discrimination using a closed-loop quantum measurement | journal = Nature | volume = 446 | issue = 11 | pages = 774–777 | year = 2007 | doi = 10.1038/nature05655 | bibcode = 2007Natur.446..774C | pmid=17429395}}</ref><ref name="Becerra2013">{{cite journal | author1 = F. E. Becerra | author2 = J. Fan | author3 = G. Baumgartner | author4 = J. Goldhar | author5 = J. T. Kosloski | author6 = A. Migdall | title = Experimental demonstration of a receiver beating the standard quantum limit for multiple nonorthogonal state discrimination | journal = Nature Photonics | volume = 7 | issue = 11 | pages = 147–152 | year = 2013 | doi = 10.1038/nphoton.2012.316 | bibcode = 2013NaPho...7..147B }}</ref> Another interesting application of weak measurements is to use weak measurements followed by a unitary to synthesize other generalized measurements.<ref name="OreshkovBrun2005">{{cite journal | author1 = O. Firey|date=20 August 2004|newspaper=Corvallis Gazette-Times|url=https://www.gazettetimes.com/news/local/obituaries/william-j-firey/article_a00e9304-c901-56fe-9d2e-8f026532ba61.html}} Born in Montana, Firey moved with his family to Seattle when he was 6 years old. During WW II, he served in the U.S. Army as a medical technician in Europe. He married in 1946. During the first years of their marriage, the couple worked for the [[United States Forest Service]] during summers in fire look-out stations in the Washington [[Cascade Range|Cascades]]. Firey received in 1948 his bachelor's degree from the University of Washington, in 1949 his master's degree from the University of Toronto, and in 1954 his Ph.D. from Stanford University. He was a faculty member at Washington State University for 8 years and then became a professor at Oregon State University, where he retired as professor emeritus in 1988. He was a visiting professor at several universities and made several trips to the [[Mathematical Research Institute of Oberwolfach]]. In 1974 Firey was an Invited Speaker at the [[International Congress of Mathematicians]] in Vancouver.{{cite book|author=Firey, W. J.|chapter=Some open questions on convex surfaces|title=''In:'' Proceedings of the International Congress of Mathematicians, 1974, Vancouver, B.C.|volume=vol. 1|pages=479–484}} {{blockquote|In addition to his professional travels, he and his wife, often joined by friends, sailed in the Pacific Northwest's San Juan and Gulf Islands, the Mediterranean seas around Greece, and the Baltic.
